abstracts.cdata!:
The Poverty Reduction Fund Project for
            Saint Lucia had the following ratings: the outcome was
            satisfactory, the sustainability was highly likely, the
            institutional development impact was modest, and the Bank
            and borrower performance were both satisfactory. The lessons
            learned indicate that the social investment fund concept can
            work as vehicle to achieve poverty reduction in small island
            countries. Communities can manage key aspects of the
            subproject cycle, and this contributes to local capacity and
            ownership. Building lasting and greater social capital is a
            long-term process. Capacity building is critical, but should
            be linked as much as possible to the labor market. Project
            design should consider the long start-up time for new
            entities. Good managers with decision-making autonomy, and
            adequate staffing, are key to successful implementation.
            Community participation fosters the appropriate selection of
            subprojects. Appropriate design and timing of monitoring and
            evaluation instruments is crucial to monitoring project
            impacts. A communications strategy would benefit the Poverty
            Reduction Fund (PRF). Duplication of donor efforts continues
            to be a concern and requires careful consideration by the
            World Bank. Diseconomies of scale in small states affects
            project performance.
